An element $e \in M$ is called a unit element or a neutral element with respect to the law of composition on $M$ if $ea = a = ae$ holds for all $a \in M$. Such a unit element $e$ is uniquely determined by its defining property; it is usually denoted as 1.

A ring (admitting a unit element) is a set R together with two laws of composition written as addition '+' and multiplication '.' such that: (i) R is a commutative group with respect to addition. (ii) R is a monoid with respect to multiplication, i.e., the multiplication is associative, and there exists a unit element in R. (iii) The distributive laws hold, i.e., (a+b) 
cdot c=a 
cdot c+b 
cdot c, and c 
cdot(a+b)=c 
cdot a+c 
cdot b for all a, b, c in R.
Does the concept of a/an Unit or Neutral Element need to be defined for a definition of a/an Ring to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of a ring explicitly states that it is a set R with two laws of composition: addition and multiplication. For addition, R must be a commutative group, which inherently includes the existence of an additive identity (zero element). For multiplication, the definition specifies that R must be a monoid. A monoid, by definition, requires the existence of a unit element (neutral element) with respect to multiplication. This unit element must satisfy the condition that multiplying it by any element of the set results in that element itself, which aligns with the definition of a unit or neutral element. Therefore, the concept of a unit or neutral element is essential for the definition of a ring, as it is part of the requirement that R be a monoid with respect to multiplication.
